column2: In former times, those severe places where the discipline of the prison delivers the convict into his own hands, were composed of four stone walls, a stone ceiling, a flagged pavement, a camp bed, a grated window, and a door lined with iron, and were called dungeons; but the dungeon was judged to be too terrible; nowadays they are composed of an iron door, a grated window, a camp bed, a flagged pavement, four stone walls, and a stone ceiling, and are called chambers of punishment.
column3: In former times, those severe places where the discipline of the prison delivers the convict into his own hands, were composed of four stone walls, a stone ceiling, a flagged pavement, a camp bed, a grated window, and a door lined with iron, and were called dungeons; but the dungeon was judged to be too terrible; nowadays they are composed of an iron door, a grated window, a camp bed, a flagged pavement, four stone walls, and a stone ceiling, and are called chambers of punishment.

column2: A little light penetrates towards mid-day.
column3: A little light penetrates towards mid day.

column2: The inconvenient point about these chambers which, as the reader sees, are not dungeons, is that they allow the persons who should be at work to think.
column3: The inconvenient point about these chambers which, as the reader sees, are not dungeons, is that they allow the persons who should be at work to think.

column2: So Brujon meditated, and he emerged from the chamber of punishment with a rope.
column3: So Brujon meditated, and he emerged from the chamber of punishment with a rope.

column2: As he had the name of being very dangerous in the Charlemagne courtyard, he was placed in the New Building.
column3: As he had the name of being very dangerous in the Charlemagne courtyard, he was placed in the New Building.

column2: The first thing he found in the New Building was Guelemer, the second was a nail; Guelemer, that is to say, crime; a nail, that is to say, liberty.
column3: The first thing he found in the New Building was Guelemer, the second was a nail; Guelemer, that is to say, crime; a nail, that is to say, liberty.

column2: Brujon, of whom it is high time that the reader should have a complete idea, was, with an appearance of delicate health and a profoundly premeditated languor, a polished, intelligent sprig, and a thief, who had a caressing glance, and an atrocious smile.
column3: Brujon, of whom it is high time that the reader should have a complete idea, was, with an appearance of delicate health and a profoundly premeditated languor, a polished, intelligent sprig, and a thief, who had a caressing glance, and an atrocious smile.

column3: His glance resulted from his will, and his smile from his nature.

column2: His first studies in his art had been directed to roofs.
column3: His first studies in his art had been directed to roofs.

column2: He had made great progress in the industry of the men who tear off lead, who plunder the roofs and despoil the gutters by the process called double pickings.
column3: He had made great progress in the industry of the men who tear off lead, who plunder the roofs and despoil the gutters by the process called double pickings.

column2: The circumstance which put the finishing touch on the moment peculiarly favorable for an attempt at escape, was that the roofers were re-laying and re-jointing, at that very moment, a portion of the slates on the prison.

column2: Up above there were scaffoldings and ladders; in other words, bridges and stairs in the direction of liberty.

column2: The New Building, which was the most cracked and decrepit thing to be seen anywhere in the world, was the weak point in the prison.
column3: The New Building, which was the most cracked and decrepit thing to be seen anywhere in the world, was the weak point in the prison.

column2: The walls were eaten by saltpetre to such an extent that the authorities had been obliged to line the vaults of the dormitories with a sheathing of wood, because stones were in the habit of becoming detached and falling on the prisoners in their beds.

column3: The New Building contained four dormitories, one above the other, and a top story which was called the Bel Air (Fine Air).

column3: A large chimney flue, probably from some ancient kitchen of the Dukes de la Force, started from the groundfloor, traversed all four stories, cut the dormitories, where it figured as a flattened pillar, into two portions, and finally pierced the roof.

column2: An abyss six feet broad and eighty feet deep separated them from the surrounding wall.

column2: They fastened one end of the rope which Brujon had spun in his dungeon to the stumps of the iron bars which they had just wrenched off, flung the other over the outer wall, crossed the abyss at one bound, clung to the coping of the wall, got astride of it, let themselves slip, one after the other, along the rope, upon a little roof which touches the bath-house, pulled their rope after them, jumped down into the courtyard of the bath-house, traversed it, pushed open the porter's wicket, beside which hung his rope, pulled this, opened the porte-cochere, and found themselves in the street.

column2: Every day, at four o'clock in the afternoon, a jailer, escorted by two dogs,--this was still in vogue at that time,--entered his cage, deposited beside his bed a loaf of black bread weighing two pounds, a jug of water, a bowl filled with rather thin bouillon, in which swam a few Mayagan beans, inspected his irons and tapped the bars. This man and his dogs made two visits during the night.

column3: This ruin can be recognized by two large square windows which are still to be seen there; the middle one, that nearest the right gable, is barred with a worm eaten beam adjusted like a prop.

column2: Had he placed the plank from his bed like a bridge from the roof of the Fine-Air to the outer wall, and crawled flat, on his belly on the coping of the outer wall the whole distance round the prison as far as the hut? But the outer wall of La Force formed a crenellated and unequal line; it mounted and descended, it dropped at the firemen's barracks, it rose towards the bath-house, it was cut in twain by buildings, it was not even of the same height on the Hotel Lamoignon as on the Rue Pavee; everywhere occurred falls and right angles; and then, the sentinels must have espied the dark form of the fugitive; hence, the route taken by Thenardier still remains rather inexplicable.

column2: In two manners, flight was impossible.

column2: Had Thenardier, spurred on by that thirst for liberty which changes precipices into ditches, iron bars into wattles of osier, a legless man into an athlete, a gouty man into a bird, stupidity into instinct, instinct into intelligence, and intelligence into genius, had Thenardier invented a third mode?

column2: The marvels of escape cannot always be accounted for.
column3: The marvels of escape cannot always be accounted for.

column2: The man who makes his escape, we repeat, is inspired; there is something of the star and of the lightning in the mysterious gleam of flight; the effort towards deliverance is no less surprising than the flight towards the sublime, and one says of the escaped thief: "How did he contrive to scale that wall?" in the same way that one says of Corneille: "Where did he find the means of dying?"
column3: The man who makes his escape, we repeat, is inspired; there is something of the star and of the lightning in the mysterious gleam of flight; the effort towards deliverance is no less surprising than the flight towards the sublime, and one says of the escaped thief: "How did he contrive to scale that wall?" in the same way that one says of Corneille: "Where did he find the means of dying?"

column2: At all events, dripping with perspiration, drenched with rain, with his clothes hanging in ribbons, his hands flayed, his elbows bleeding, his knees torn, Thenardier had reached what children, in their figurative language, call the edge of the wall of the ruin, there he had stretched himself out at full length, and there his strength had failed him.
column3: At all events, dripping with perspiration, drenched with rain, with his clothes hanging in ribbons, his hands flayed, his elbows bleeding, his knees torn, Thenardier had reached what children, in their figurative language, call the edge of the wall of the ruin, there he had stretched himself out at full length, and there his strength had failed him.

column2: A steep escarpment three stories high separated him from the pavement of the street.
column3: A steep escarpment three stories high separated him from the pavement of the street.

column2: The rope which he had was too short.
column3: The rope which he had was too short.

column2: There he waited, pale, exhausted, desperate with all the despair which he had undergone, still hidden by the night, but telling himself that the day was on the point of dawning, alarmed at the idea of hearing the neighboring clock of Saint-Paul strike four within a few minutes, an hour when the sentinel was relieved and when the latter would be found asleep under the pierced roof, staring in horror at a terrible depth, at the light of the street lanterns, the wet, black pavement, that pavement longed for yet frightful, which meant death, and which meant liberty.
column3: There he waited, pale, exhausted, desperate with all the despair which he had undergone, still hidden by the night, but telling himself that the day was on the point of dawning, alarmed at the idea of hearing the neighboring clock of Saint Paul strike four within a few minutes, an hour when the sentinel was relieved and when the latter would be found asleep under the pierced roof, staring in horror at a terrible depth, at the light of the street lanterns, the wet, black pavement, that pavement longed for yet frightful, which meant death, and which meant liberty.

column2: He asked himself whether his three accomplices in flight had succeeded, if they had heard him, and if they would come to his assistance.
column3: He asked himself whether his three accomplices in flight had succeeded, if they had heard him, and if they would come to his assistance.

column2: He listened.
column3: He listened.

column2: With the exception of the patrol, no one had passed through the street since he had been there.
column3: With the exception of the patrol, no one had passed through the street since he had been there.

column2: Nearly the whole of the descent of the market-gardeners from Montreuil, from Charonne, from Vincennes, and from Bercy to the markets was accomplished through the Rue Saint-Antoine.
column3: Nearly the whole of the descent of the market gardeners from Montreuil, from Charonne, from Vincennes, and from Bercy to the markets was accomplished through the Rue Saint Antoine.

column2: Four o'clock struck.
column3: Four o'clock struck.

column2: Thenardier shuddered.
column3: Thenardier shuddered.

column2: A few moments later, that terrified and confused uproar which follows the discovery of an escape broke forth in the prison.
column3: A few moments later, that terrified and confused uproar which follows the discovery of an escape broke forth in the prison.

column2: The sound of doors opening and shutting, the creaking of gratings on their hinges, a tumult in the guard-house, the hoarse shouts of the turnkeys, the shock of musket-butts on the pavement of the courts, reached his ears.
column3: The sound of doors opening and shutting, the creaking of gratings on their hinges, a tumult in the guard house, the hoarse shouts of the turnkeys, the shock of musket butts on the pavement of the courts, reached his ears.

column2: Lights ascended and descended past the grated windows of the dormitories, a torch ran along the ridge-pole of the top story of the New Building, the firemen belonging in the barracks on the right had been summoned.
column3: Lights ascended and descended past the grated windows of the dormitories, a torch ran along the ridge pole of the top story of the New Building, the firemen belonging in the barracks on the right had been summoned.

column2: Their helmets, which the torch lighted up in the rain, went and came along the roofs.
column3: Their helmets, which the torch lighted up in the rain, went and came along the roofs.

column2: At the same time, Thenardier perceived in the direction of the Bastille a wan whiteness lighting up the edge of the sky in doleful wise.
column3: At the same time, Thenardier perceived in the direction of the Bastille a wan whiteness lighting up the edge of the sky in doleful wise.

column2: He was on top of a wall ten inches wide, stretched out under the heavy rains, with two gulfs to right and left, unable to stir, subject to the giddiness of a possible fall, and to the horror of a certain arrest, and his thoughts, like the pendulum of a clock, swung from one of these ideas to the other: "Dead if I fall, caught if I stay." In the midst of this anguish, he suddenly saw, the street being still dark, a man who was gliding along the walls and coming from the Rue Pavee, halt in the recess above which Thenardier was, as it were, suspended.

In the midst of this anguish, he suddenly saw, the street being still dark, a man who was gliding along the walls and coming from the Rue Pavee, halt in the recess above which Thenardier was, as it were, suspended.

column2: Here this man was joined by a second, who walked with the same caution, then by a third, then by a fourth.
column3: Here this man was joined by a second, who walked with the same caution, then by a third, then by a fourth.

column3: When these men were re united, one of them lifted the latch of the gate in the fence, and all four entered the enclosure in which the shanty stood.

column2: They halted directly under Thenardier.
column3: They halted directly under Thenardier.

column2: These men had evidently chosen this vacant space in order that they might consult without being seen by the passers-by or by the sentinel who guards the wicket of La Force a few paces distant.
column3: These men had evidently chosen this vacant space in order that they might consult without being seen by the passers by or by the sentinel who guards the wicket of La Force a few paces distant.

column2: It must be added, that the rain kept this sentinel blocked in his box. Thenardier, not being able to distinguish their visages, lent an ear to their words with the desperate attention of a wretch who feels himself lost.
column3: It must be added, that the rain kept this sentinel blocked in his box. Thenardier, not being able to distinguish their visages, lent an ear to their words with the desperate attention of a wretch who feels himself lost.

column2: Thenardier saw something resembling a gleam of hope flash before his eyes,--these men conversed in slang.

column2: The first said in a low but distinct voice:--
column3: The first said in a low but distinct voice:--

column2: What are we up to here?"
column3: What are we up to here?"

column2: The second replied: "It's raining hard enough to put out the very devil's fire.

column2: And the bobbies will be along instanter.

column3: There's a soldier on guard yonder.

column2: We shall get nabbed here."
column3: We shall get nabbed here."

column2: These two words, icigo and icicaille, both of which mean ici, and which belong, the first to the slang of the barriers, the second to the slang of the Temple, were flashes of light for Thenardier.
column3: These two words, icigo and icicaille, both of which mean i c i, and which belong, the first to the slang of the barriers, the second to the slang of the Temple, were flashes of light for Thenardier.

column2: By the icigo he recognized Brujon, who was a prowler of the barriers, by the icicaille he knew Babet, who, among his other trades, had been an old-clothes broker at the Temple.
column3: By the icigo he recognized Brujon, who was a prowler of the barriers, by the icicaille he knew Babet, who, among his other trades, had been an old clothes broker at the Temple.

column2: The antique slang of the great century is no longer spoken except in the Temple, and Babet was really the only person who spoke it in all its purity.
column3: The antique slang of the great century is no longer spoken except in the Temple, and Babet was really the only person who spoke it in all its purity.

column2: In the meanwhile, the third man had intervened.
column3: In the meanwhile, the third man had intervened.

column2: How do we know that he doesn't stand in need of us?"
column3: How do we know that he doesn't stand in need of us?"

column2: Thenardier did not hesitate.

column2: It was Guelemer.

column2: Brujon replied almost impetuously but still in a low tone:--
column3: Brujon replied almost impetuously but still in a low tone:--

column2: What are you jabbering about?	What are you jabbering about?
column3: true

column2: The tavern-keeper hasn't managed to cut his stick.
column3: The tavern keeper hasn't managed to cut his stick.

column2: He don't tumble to the racket, that he don't!
column3: He don't tumble to the racket, that he don't!

column2: You have to be a pretty knowing cove to tear up your shirt, cut up your sheet to make a rope, punch holes in doors, get up false papers, make false keys, file your irons, hang out your cord, hide yourself, and disguise yourself! The old fellow hasn't managed to play it, he doesn't understand how to work the business."

column2: Babet added, still in that classical slang which was spoken by Poulailler and Cartouche, and which is to the bold, new, highly colored and risky argot used by Brujon what the language of Racine is to the language of Andre Chenier:--
column3: Babet added, still in that classical slang which was spoken by Poulailler and Cartouche, and which is to the bold, new, highly colored and risky argot used by Brujon what the language of Racine is to the language of Andre Chenier:--

column2: Your tavern-keeper must have been nabbed in the act.	Your tavern keeper must have been nabbed in the act.

column2: You have to be knowing.

column2: He's only a greenhorn.
column3: He's only a greenhorn.

column2: He must have let himself be taken in by a bobby, perhaps even by a sheep who played it on him as his pal. Listen, Montparnasse, do you hear those shouts in the prison?
column3: He must have let himself be taken in by a bobby, perhaps even by a sheep who played it on him as his pal. Listen, Montparnasse, do you hear those shouts in the prison?

column2: You have seen all those lights.

column2: He's recaptured, there!
column3: He's recaptured, there!

column2: He'll get off with twenty years.
column3: He'll get off with twenty years.

column2: Don't get mad, come with us, let's go drink a bottle of old wine together."
column3: Don't get mad, come with us, let's go drink a bottle of old wine together."

column2: One doesn't desert one's friends in a scrape, grumbled Montparnasse.
column3: One doesn't desert one's friends in a scrape, grumbled Montparnasse.

column2: I tell you he's nabbed! retorted Brujon.
column3: I tell you he's nabbed! retorted Brujon.

column2: We can't do nothing for him.

column2: Let's be off.

column2: Every minute I think a bobby has got me in his fist."
column3: Every minute I think a bobby has got me in his fist."

column2: Montparnasse no longer offered more than a feeble resistance; the fact is, that these four men, with the fidelity of ruffians who never abandon each other, had prowled all night long about La Force, great as was their peril, in the hope of seeing Thenardier make his appearance on the top of some wall.

column2: But the night, which was really growing too fine,--for the downpour was such as to render all the streets deserted,--the cold which was overpowering them, their soaked garments, their hole-ridden shoes, the alarming noise which had just burst forth in the prison, the hours which had elapsed, the patrol which they had encountered, the hope which was vanishing, all urged them to beat a retreat.
column3: But the night, which was really growing too fine,--for the downpour was such as to render all the streets deserted,--the cold which was overpowering them, their soaked garments, their hole ridden shoes, the alarming noise which had just burst forth in the prison, the hours which had elapsed, the patrol which they had encountered, the hope which was vanishing, all urged them to beat a retreat.

column2: Montparnasse himself, who was, perhaps, almost Thenardier's son-in-law, yielded.
column3: Montparnasse himself, who was, perhaps, almost Thenardier's son in law, yielded.

column2: A moment more, and they would be gone.

column2: Thenardier was panting on his wall like the shipwrecked sufferers of the Meduse on their raft when they beheld the vessel which had appeared in sight vanish on the horizon.
column3: Thenardier was panting on his wall like the shipwrecked sufferers of the Meduse on their raft when they beheld the vessel which had appeared in sight vanish on the horizon.

column2: He dared not call to them; a cry might be heard and ruin everything.
column3: He dared not call to them; a cry might be heard and ruin everything.

column3: An idea occurred to him, a last idea, a flash of inspiration; he drew from his pocket the end of Brujon's rope, which he had detached from the chimney of the New Building, and flung it into the space enclosed by the fence.

column2: This rope fell at their feet.
column3: This rope fell at their feet.

column2: A widow,[37] said Babet.

column2: My tortouse![38] said Brujon.

column2: The tavern-keeper is there, said Montparnasse.
column3: The tavern keeper is there, said Montparnasse.

column3: They raised their eyes.

column2: Yes.

column3: Knot the two pieces together, we'll fling him the rope, he can fasten it to the wall, and he'll have enough of it to get down with.

column2: Thenardier ran the risk, and spoke:--
column3: Thenardier ran the risk, and spoke:--

column2: I am paralyzed with cold.
column3: I am paralyzed with cold.

column2: We'll warm you up.
column3: We'll warm you up.

column2: I can't budge.
column3: I can't budge.

column2: Let yourself slide, we'll catch you.

column2: I can't.

column2: Then one of us must climb up, said Montparnasse.
column3: Then one of us must climb up, said Montparnasse.

column2: Three stories! ejaculated Brujon.
column3: Three stories! ejaculated Brujon.

column2: An ancient plaster flue, which had served for a stove that had been used in the shanty in former times, ran along the wall and mounted almost to the very spot where they could see Thenardier.
column3: An ancient plaster flue, which had served for a stove that had been used in the shanty in former times, ran along the wall and mounted almost to the very spot where they could see Thenardier.

column2: This flue, then much damaged and full of cracks, has since fallen, but the marks of it are still visible.
column3: This flue, then much damaged and full of cracks, has since fallen, but the marks of it are still visible.

column2: It was very narrow.
column3: It was very narrow.

column2: One might get up by the help of that, said Montparnasse.

column3: By that flue? exclaimed Babet, "a grown up cove, never! it would take a brat."

column3: A brat must be got, resumed Brujon.

column3: Where are we to find a young 'un? said Guelemer.

column2: Wait, said Montparnasse.
column3: Wait, said Montparnasse.

column2: I've got the very article.
column3: I've got the very article.

column2: He opened the gate of the fence very softly, made sure that no one was passing along the street, stepped out cautiously, shut the gate behind him, and set off at a run in the direction of the Bastille.
column3: He opened the gate of the fence very softly, made sure that no one was passing along the street, stepped out cautiously, shut the gate behind him, and set off at a run in the direction of the Bastille.

column2: Seven or eight minutes elapsed, eight thousand centuries to Thenardier; Babet, Brujon, and Guelemer did not open their lips; at last the gate opened once more, and Montparnasse appeared, breathless, and followed by Gavroche.
column3: Seven or eight minutes elapsed, eight thousand centuries to Thenardier; Babet, Brujon, and Guelemer did not open their lips; at last the gate opened once more, and Montparnasse appeared, breathless, and followed by Gavroche.

column2: The rain still rendered the street completely deserted.
column3: The rain still rendered the street completely deserted.

column2: Little Gavroche entered the enclosure and gazed at the forms of these ruffians with a tranquil air.
column3: Little Gavroche entered the enclosure and gazed at the forms of these ruffians with a tranquil air.

column2: The water was dripping from his hair. Guelemer addressed him:--
column3: The water was dripping from his hair. Guelemer addressed him:--

column3: Are you a man, young 'un?

column2: Gavroche shrugged his shoulders, and replied:--
column3: Gavroche shrugged his shoulders, and replied:--

column2: A young 'un like me's a man, and men like you are babes.
column3: A young 'un like me's a man, and men like you are babes.

column2: The brat's tongue's well hung! exclaimed Babet.
column3: The brat's tongue's well hung! exclaimed Babet.

column3: The Paris brat ain't made of straw, added Brujon.

column3: What do you want? asked Gavroche.

column3: Montparnasse answered:--

column3: Climb up that flue.

column3: With this rope, said Babet.

column2: And fasten it, continued Brujon.
column3: And fasten it, continued Brujon.

column3: To the cross bar of the window, added Brujon.

column3: And then? said Gavroche.

column2: There! said Guelemer.
column3: There! said Guelemer.

column3: The gamin examined the rope, the flue, the wall, the windows, and made that indescribable and disdainful noise with his lips which signifies:--

column2: Is that all!
column3: Is that all!

column2: There's a man up there whom you are to save, resumed Montparnasse.
column3: There's a man up there whom you are to save, resumed Montparnasse.

column3: Will you? began Brujon again.

column2: Greenhorn! replied the lad, as though the question appeared a most unprecedented one to him.

column2: Guelemer seized Gavroche by one arm, set him on the roof of the shanty, whose worm-eaten planks bent beneath the urchin's weight, and handed him the rope which Brujon had knotted together during Montparnasse's absence.
column3: Guelemer seized Gavroche by one arm, set him on the roof of the shanty, whose worm eaten planks bent beneath the urchin's weight, and handed him the rope which Brujon had knotted together during Montparnasse's absence.

column3: The gamin directed his steps towards the flue, which it was easy to enter, thanks to a large crack which touched the roof.

column2: At the moment when he was on the point of ascending, Thenardier, who saw life and safety approaching, bent over the edge of the wall; the first light of dawn struck white upon his brow dripping with sweat, upon his livid cheek-bones, his sharp and savage nose, his bristling gray beard, and Gavroche recognized him.
column3: At the moment when he was on the point of ascending, Thenardier, who saw life and safety approaching, bent over the edge of the wall; the first light of dawn struck white upon his brow dripping with sweat, upon his livid cheek bones, his sharp and savage nose, his bristling gray beard, and Gavroche recognized him.

column3: He reached the summit of the hut, bestrode the old wall as though it had been a horse, and knotted the rope firmly to the upper cross bar of the window.

column2: A moment later, Thenardier was in the street.
column3: A moment later, Thenardier was in the street.

column2: As soon as he touched the pavement, as soon as he found himself out of danger, he was no longer either weary, or chilled or trembling; the terrible things from which he had escaped vanished like smoke, all that strange and ferocious mind awoke once more, and stood erect and free, ready to march onward.
column3: As soon as he touched the pavement, as soon as he found himself out of danger, he was no longer either weary, or chilled or trembling; the terrible things from which he had escaped vanished like smoke, all that strange and ferocious mind awoke once more, and stood erect and free, ready to march onward.

column2: These were this man's first words:--
column3: These were this man's first words:--

column2: Now, whom are we to eat?
column3: Now, whom are we to eat?

column2: It is useless to explain the sense of this frightfully transparent remark, which signifies both to kill, to assassinate, and to plunder.
column3: It is useless to explain the sense of this frightfully transparent remark, which signifies both to kill, to assassinate, and to plunder.

column3: Still, it must be seen to.

column3: And off he went.

column2: The five men emerged, one after another, from the enclosure.
column3: The five men emerged, one after another, from the enclosure.

column2: When Gavroche had disappeared at the corner of the Rue des Ballets, Babet took Thenardier aside.
column3: When Gavroche had disappeared at the corner of the Rue des Ballets, Babet took Thenardier aside.

column2: Did you take a good look at that young 'un? he asked.
column3: Did you take a good look at that young 'un? he asked.

column2: What young 'un?

column2: The one who climbed the wall and carried you the rope.
column3: The one who climbed the wall and carried you the rope.

column2: Well, I don't know, but it strikes me that it was your son.

column2: Pigritia is a terrible word.

column2: It engenders a whole world, la pegre, for which read theft, and a hell, la pegrenne, for which read hunger.
